subtitle: hi I'm Simon Jacobson welcome to
meaningful Monday's where we answer your
personal questions the question for this
week is I have some social issues I have
a hard time relating to other people I
don't know how to start conversations
and I feel like I have nothing to talk
about with other people it makes me feel
like an isolated loser and I need help
it's critical they not allow your
attitudes to magnify and accentuate the
problem so sometimes some of us for
example are not conversationalist or
like in this case someone may not feel
so social but to start beating yourself
up because of it often creates a bigger
problem than the original problem
because then you get demoralized you get
depressed and then you don't even have
the strength to fight the issue so it's
critical to do this in two stages half
of a cure of any problem is awareness of
the problem and the second half is going
in with a positive and optimistic
attitude once you've identified this is
the issue let me deal with it any type
of issue that makes you stand out makes
you feel isolated it makes you feel
lonely makes you feel different allow
that to demoralise you then the problem
becomes far harder to deal with so let's
distinguish between the two if it's
objectively true that you have social
issues how do we determine that you have
to ask some people some people that care
about you it could be family members it
could be friends three people you trust
find out do you really have social
issues or maybe it's in your head maybe
you've just not been used to accustomed
to dealing with social situations maybe
your parents are loners maybe for some
other reason I know somebody who avoid
going to party simply one thing because
they were afraid they would stutter they
actually didn't starter that much but
they did once or twice and very
embarrassing they just avoided it to the
point they became loners or is it true
that you do maybe have a certain
introverted personality will you thrive
more reading a book being alone so it's
critical to establish what is the true
status an objective status of your
situation if it's established that you
are not that so
so don't beat yourself up so what some
people are party animals some are not
there are many strengths that a person
has can be more introspective someone
can be more insightful nobody is a
pariah so if you can see yourself
positively you have to look at your
personality identify what it really is
like accentuate the strengths and if you
do have a weakness we all have
weaknesses don't beat yourself up so the
feeling of isolation because you're
different they're not appropriate why
don't you see it like that maybe your
unique and you need people who reinforce
and give you that type of confidence
obviously if you're going to hang around
with people criticize you and laugh at
you not exactly going to help the
situation so the key here is to divide
this into parts and recognize what
exactly is the issue is the issue with
what you like is it how you feel about
yourself is how the people you're
hanging around with and what attitudes
they have if you can divide this if far
easier to find a solution to the issue
people some people extremely internal
have achieved unbelievable things in
life and some people who are extremely
social have been very destructive Nolan
says that a social party person is
necessarily the best type of person
everything has its role and we have to
have times where we are more introverted
that sometimes when were more extrovert
thank you for watching I welcome your
questions have a meaningful week
